author: {'steamid': '76561199010042150', 'num_games_owned': 3874, 'num_reviews': 2454, 'playtime_forever': 200, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 200, 'last_played': 1649372189}
review:
I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right handâ€”the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bedâ€”the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198146380929', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 224, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1663009437}
review:
A unique roguelike dungeon crawler, that is so simple but still highly engaging. 

I will start with the good in the game. First, the freedom to remap the controls and play in many different resolutions is something I appreciate. Second, the game plays so well that I am confused when others say it is a chore. The game is very simple. But, I don't think that makes it repetitive or boring at all. I think the game has good depth, considering how simple it is. Which brings me to my next point, the choices. You can choose so much: to what class you want to play, to what items you want to use, what stats to increase when you level up, if you want to leave a floor or keep exploring for more loot, if you want to replay a dungeon, and etc. Lastly, the random dungeon generation makes this game highly replayable, since you can go into the same dungeon hundreds of times and it will be different every time.

Now, onto the bad. Starting with the combat, it is good combat but I do not like the lack of an indicator when a monster attacks you. Otherwise, trying to block the monster's attack becomes a guessing game and you have to memorize the attack patterns for every monster since every monster has different attack patterns which is cool, but not so cool when it is hard to tell when to actually block each of those attacks. The tutorial tries to teach you blocking with a single monster but is very vague and says to just block shortly after you attack because that is when the monster attacks. That is it, they never warn you that other monsters have different attack patterns. And I keep complaining about this because, it really does matter. When you get hit in this game, it really hurts! Ways to heal yourself are limited. So, when you get hit in this game, it feels unfair and that is because it is. Moving along, I will also mention the amount of clicking. The game plays like a clicker game at times and that is because this game was a mobile port, as others here have mentioned. That I will admit is repetitive and should of been reworked with more care in mind, for the hands of their players. Finally, the user interface. Or, for short, the UI. The UI is not good. One thing it needs is a button for the stats and inventory of the player, since as of right now, you have to right click on your character then click one of the options. Which is redundant, since you go to these pages often, they should just be on the same page as the other information. The UI also should not have items you find go on top of the screen but under your character. This is because it will not only look better, but will also prevent the player from having to exhaust their eyes, switching from 3 places. The item bar, the dungeon, and the player area. And could be just in 2 places, the dungeon and the player area with item bar. I could go on and on about what is wrong with the UI but those were some examples.

author: {'steamid': '76561198268537934', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 243, 'playtime_forever': 814, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 814, 'last_played': 1655598410}
review:
Dungeon Journey is a very good rogue-like game.

Pros:
+You can unlock a lot of characters in the dungeon.
+Kill monsters to get EXP, defend yourself by using a shield.
+Every level up will give you some points to improve your skills.
+Gather magic stones to upgrade your equipment.
+You don't need to destroy every boss of dungeon, just get one star at least in order to pass it.
+Sometimes you will find a portal gate in the dungeon. It can be used as a save point.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077147190', 'num_games_owned': 1268, 'num_reviews': 219, 'playtime_forever': 23, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23, 'last_played': 1617796613}
review:
Ob ich das Tutorial spielen will? Nein, ich wollte erst einmal die VIEL zu laute Musik runterregeln. Ging aber nicht, man konnte sie nur ein- oder ausschalten. Also regelte ich den Sound eben Ã¼ber Windows herunter. Danach gabs nicht mehr die MÃ¶glichkeit, das Tutorial zu spielen. Auch nicht nach Neustart und Deinstallation. Also die versteckte Datei in Regedit von Hand gesucht und gelÃ¶scht. Dann konnte es losgehen... 
Zu viel mehr als einem Antesten der beiden Heldenklassen, die zu Beginn verfÃ¼gbar sind, hat die Motivation dann aber nicht mehr gereicht. Die Zauberin wirkt zu schwach. Eben wie bei einem typischen Handyspiel, nur dass man hier kein Echtgeld einsetzen kann. Der Ritter ist ganz ok. Aber es ist kein Held, bei dem ich mich wie bei anderen Rollenspielen aufs Leveln freuen wÃ¼rde.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072270357', 'num_games_owned': 438, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 918, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21, 'last_played': 1620910229}
review: I bought this game along with many other games when they were on 90% sale. If you're buying this on sale, I recommend it. The way the game works is really interesting, it's one of the few games that I kept playing after getting my card drops. It might get a bit repetitive later on and you might become unkillable if you figure out how to block every attack, but for its price, I think it's alright, especially if it's on a sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198088446709', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 9742, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1133, 'last_played': 1683321405}
review: At first I was not sure I would like this game as it seemed too simple -- click open blocks in the rooms in the "dungeon" and uncover treasure or monsters -- but it turned out to have some strategy involved with fighting the monsters and even opening the blocks, depending upon which character you were  playing at the time.  My only real complaint is that you can't stop playing in the middle of a dungeon and then pick it up again there later, so I have to be sure I have enough time to finish when I begin or lose that progress.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052754386', 'num_games_owned': 360, 'num_reviews': 201, 'playtime_forever': 768, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 768, 'last_played': 1601320141}
review: Dungeon Journey is a very simplistic action RPG that features stats, skills and gear for each class. Gameplay is based around dodging (blocking) your enemies attacks in correct moment. There are a lot of enemies but they can be categorized by timing  of blocking their attacks. They attack you after you attack them, you mostly have a visual cue as to when to press block button. Some of them require you to block the moment your weapon finishes its attack animation, some when they fire a beam at you and some of them have slightly more difficult timing. It is easy and very repetitive. Loot doesn't really make you more powerful but grinding gems and inserting them into your gear sockets do. There are a few main dungeons but the game doesn't have an ending even if you finish them all, it allows you to grind hardest difficulty infinite dungeons after completing the game just for sake of grinding. It is a fun game but you shouldn't expect much. It is made for mobile gaming after all.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025630223', 'num_games_owned': 3301, 'num_reviews': 297, 'playtime_forever': 529, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 529, 'last_played': 1594944616}
review:
I could see this being fun on mobile, but on PC it's not great.  The fact that the aspect ratio is still that of a vertical phone screen is extremely lazy.  Being a port of a mobile game, the pacing for the game is quick and designed for short periods of timeâ€”great for waiting for an appointment or on public transit, but no so much when sitting down to actually put some game time in.  And again, because it's a mobile game, the controls fail pretty hard because the game is designed for tapping and swipingâ€”things you simply cannot do in the PC version.  Decent mobile game, bad PC game.

[h1]4/10[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198037638877', 'num_games_owned': 329, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1622, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 199, 'last_played': 1587807395}
review:
This is actually a really good game. I would gladly recommend this game to rogue-like dungeon crawler fans.
People complain about it being a mobile port, but so what. It is still a good game and it is not as if you'll spend your whole month's salary on it. It is quite cheap and well worth the price. Just don't expect a AAA game for this price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042406453', 'num_games_owned': 1063, 'num_reviews': 752, 'playtime_forever': 1311, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1311, 'last_played': 1582947658}
review:
[b]dungeon journey[/b] is a roguelike dungeon crawler, much like [b]dungelot[/b] or [b]runestone keeper[/b], including certain mobile-like qualities, but for the fraction of the price. if you've played any of those, you'll be in familiar territory, just click on tiles, see what's there and deal with it.

10 main dungeons, each 5 floors longer than the last, some with bosses at the end. defeating those unlocks 3 additional classes on top of the 2 available from the start. there are also 5 endless dungeons.

it's a roguelike, so turn-based combat, random levels and permadeath are a given. [b]quick-time events[/b] not so much, but you have to block enemy attacks here either by clicking on the shield or pressing space at the right time. different monsters have different attack speeds, it needs some getting used to, and some attack as soon as they're revealed (including the penultimate boss), even harder to avoid. however, I liked certain abilities that would trigger on a perfect block and hurt multiple enemies, so there's an upside to qte, I just wasn't very good at it.

each class has 2 active and 2 passive skills, and attributes like hp, mana, attack, defense, agility and perception. all self-explanatory, except [b]perception[/b], which occasionally [b]lets you see what's behind certain tiles[/b]. these can be increased further with items, which in turn can be further improved by slotting gems into them. every level up gives you 1 skill and 2 attribute points, [b]the level cap is 40[/b]

gems can be combined into bigger gems at the mystic around halfway through the map, and based on where you put them, they give different bonuses. there's also a blacksmith that upgrades existing gear stats, and respec is an option as well, but I found that xp really slows down after level 30 and gold isn't exactly flooding in either (though there are gems to increase the chances of both), so as you'd imagine, grinding is the name of the game.

when you die, xp, money and items are kept, you only lose relics found in the dungeon that give even more bonuses. [b]checkpoints pop up every 5 floors in regular dungeons[/b], can be activated with more and more money to start there next time, but if you die during the second attempt, back to floor 1.

I really liked the graphics and all the characters are animated nicely (can be turned off), the music and sounds were fine too, but no volume settings. resolutions and windowed mode via the unity launcher, but not much effort went into turning the mobile game into a proper pc version, so 2/3 of the screen is wasted, pop-ups cover the level and the inventory and character sheet must be brought up separately with more clicks than necessary.

all in all, it's a bit of a mixed bag, but content and variety is good enough, and the low price matches the mobile-like qualities. I only played with one class, had no interest in doing the same thing with different characters, but it still kept me busy for 15+ hours, and if you want to conquer every dungeon with every character, you'll be at it for a lot longer.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990442840', 'num_games_owned': 518, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 14, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1578423596}

author: {'steamid': '76561198030784015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11208, 'playtime_forever': 1124, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1124, 'last_played': 1576059317}
review:
Dungeon Journey is a mobile app that's been dumped on Steam as a cheap, lazy cash grab.  It's a mobile ported (as you can tell from the portrait aspect ratio) clicker game where you click on various tiles in randomly generated "dungeons" to see if you get a monster, some loot, or nothing.  Repeat this endlessly to progress to the next randomly generated dungeon and start clicking all over again.    

Apart from the fact it's a mobile port and thus immediately fails to meet PC game standards, the fixed aspect ratio, samey gameplay, awful translation, repetitive clicking and general low effort overall here makes this impossible to recommend.   This isn't even a top contender in the mobile game stores, so why would you pay extra money to play this on PC instead of a PC game?

Once more we see greedy mobile devs trying to screw over PC gamers. On Steam, this is $2 USD, on app stores, it's 99c. Mobile devs must learn PC gamers are not here to be gouged, and can't be expected to pay TWICE as much for a crappy bundle worsening mobile game so they can pretend their gaming rigs are iPhones.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013990072', 'num_games_owned': 1513, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 1426, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1143, 'last_played': 1578249143}
review:
Okay, so here's the thing. This game does NOT deserve the playtime I'm giving it. As many others have said, it's basically a PC port of a mobile game, and it has all the features of a mobile game you might get annoyed with outside of the microtransaction elements. It's clunky, simplistic, you really don't have to pay much attention to it and all you do is repeat the same 2-3 minute long pattern of behavior with each level you play, regardless of class, regardless of enemies, regardless of difficulty or your equipment. It doesn't look appealing, it has barely any soundtrack, it may get boring and repetitive real fast if you focus on it too much.

That's not to say it doesn't have anything to go for it. You still have class variety with distinctive features and abilities that change your playstyle A LITTLE, enemy variety that you need different timings or strategies applied to, a plethora of spells and relics that you can stumble upon within the dungeon to help you get through the level, and the general repeatable pattern works for what it is - a mobile game... on PC. And it's also very cheap.

By itself, the game is something around 5/10. Has things going for it, but it's just not interesting enough to spend too much time on it instead of playing a different, likely a better game.


HOWEVER, I've been using this game as a distraction for my hands while I was watching Youtube videos and Twitch streams. It's so painfully simplistic and requires no mental effort to play it whatsoever, that it's perfect to play in windowed mode as a distraction while doing something else entirely.

This game is essentially my leisure game to play when I do better things with the remaining 99% of my brainpower. It has become another one of my Civ5/Minecraft/Morrowind games to occupy myself while doing something else.

For that, and on that basis, I give it a Recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989290281', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 315, 'playtime_forever': 22, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1532975718}
review:
https://youtu.be/88WHGldQsNU

I have to be honest - I found this game to actually be quite boring. The action is fairly dull, and the pace pretty slow, and I get the feeling this has mobile port written all over it. Click LMB to attack and then hold space bar to block. 

However the fact that the Devs have put the effort into the graphics and presentation deserves credit. The sounds are decent and at least the game doesn't crash.

If you really like RPG lite dungeon crawlers that with fairly basic mechanics, then you will probably get more out of it. But this game is just not for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030646904', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 402, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 264, 'last_played': 1530995557}
review: I'm hooked.  I've poured my last 10 hours into this simple, unpretentious, thrilling dungeon RPG that I dropped like 60 cents on during the Steam Summer Sale.  This game is so fun I don't even know what to compare it to.  It's like a tabletop Diablo II that's been filtered down to only the most fun elements of the game.  Absolutely pick this up, I'm having more fun with this than a $90 AAA title.

review: A fun puzzle/rpg type game on the cheap side. The game is easy to pick up and just play for a bit and leave and come back when your ready to be punished again. Health is in very short supply it's what will stop your progress very quickly. Threre is little you can do with out having hp/mana pots to the game, you might get 6 floors down and your hp and mana are down to nothing all you can do is hope the rng gods drop a pot so you can explore a bit more. A (even slight) recovery between floors would help progress or even an artifact that slowly recovered hp per turn would help. The only real way you will progress is grinding levels and beast past the trash.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064850410', 'num_games_owned': 770, 'num_reviews': 374, 'playtime_forever': 848, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 848, 'last_played': 1525559372}
review:
[b]Dungeon Journey[/b] is a turn-based, glorified clicker and annoyingly addicting but casual dungeon crawler with lite RPG elements.

The game has you clicking tiles and this counts as turn, any time you clear a tile or click on an enemy it counts as a turn. So the basic gameplay loop is clear tile, pick up item or leave it there if still clearing the floor of dungeon, kill monsters, perform ripostes, find the key for the floor, go to next floor, finish dungeon. Blah blah blah. You get it. 

Once further down the map you'll have access to a merchant to sell or buy items, a mystic that allows you to combine gems in the vein of something like a Diablo. Wherein the gem is then applied to armor/weapons or gear to increase its stats as you see fit. Further on from there you'll have access to a blacksmith. 

The game has a progression that can be quite satisfying. It has mildly themed dungeons along the way as well as much harder endless dungeons on the sides. The game can be a bit grindy but honestly, that's exactly what you should expect going in. 

There are 5 classes (of which I can see given my time in game, there might be more). And they all play slightly different. For instance, The Knight has things like shield bash which will stun enemies for a turn decreasing the chance of a critical missed riposte, the Sorceress has things like poison that will take affect after each turn for 3 turns and so. Each class with 2 active spells and 2 passive abilities. Each level you can spend 1 point into 1 for those 4 skills and 2 into things like health, defense, attack, agility and perception. All of those are pretty self explanatory. However, in this context, perception can at times give you hints as to what is under a tile before you clear it. Agility traditionally increases dodge chance but here it reduces the delay between input and when the shield is actively guarding you. Which can be activated by clicking on yourself or pressing spacebar. 

The enemy characters also have traits. Such things as they will spawn henchmen after 3 turns, or compel other revealed creatures to attack at the same time making it much harder to defend. Among other traits. Like bat or snake creatures that will attack immediately upon clearing a tile, giving almost no time to react. Every enemy has a slightly different timing so there is this very simple layering of systems on each other and with the slight delays in button presses make up this game in a very addictive whilst being almost completely mindless way. There are also â€œfoundâ€ spells that cost mana to use within the dungeons as well as relics that can buff or debuff you that will disappear after the dungeon is complete or death occurs. 

[b][i]THE GIST
A great addicting palate cleanser, great for shutting your mind off while watching Twitch streams or YouTube. You know, internet crap.[/i][/b]

[quote]More here â€” [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/28295405/]Station Argus[/url][/quote]

author: {'steamid': '76561198414810307', 'num_games_owned': 116, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 6, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1524164520}
review: Video and screenshots made me buy the game and hope for more. Sadly, there is nothing more. And it screams 'mobile port'. But don't get me wrong - I actually have nothing against desktop ports of mobiles game - IF they are done RIGHT. This over here is sadly not. I mean, come on - even the game launcher is the default Unity launcher. The game could easily gain a solid recommendation from me if it would offer more content and desktop port would be an ACTUAL port - not just copy paste from mobile to desktop. And to be in this poor state 2 years after initial release...? Sorry but no. Not even for such a low price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009474997', 'num_games_owned': 2217, 'num_reviews': 1072, 'playtime_forever': 115, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 115, 'last_played': 1511169635}
review:
A very simple game that does require getting used to, but in the end it can be quite fun, offering you at least some entertainment or to just kill some time.
The game does lack a bit of contend, so i think it's slightly over priced for what it offers.

What we have here is a mixture of RPG and Rogue like gameplay, you have a character that uncovers tiles as you click them one at a time, some may have treasures whilst others have enemies you have to fight. Killing them rewards items and XP to level up.

All in all this game does offer quite a bit in terms of fun and even the combat mechanics is quite decently done, there is a few characters to choose from.

A must have for any RPG fan.

review: Ok now Seriously I dont know what you did to this game and at this price- to make it so addictive..Is it the retro feel? Is it the sound effects? Is it the Creature Graphics? THANK YOU!! really very much....I think...(sublinal messaging I bet!!!) Alliens involved in the development?!  REALLY WHATS THE SECRET!!!? What ever its relly fun..Good JOB!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198030390305', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1212, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23, 'last_played': 1546364091}
review:
This is rough. This game might be worthwhile on android or iphone but there are sooo many better games you can play for free on pc. 

The gameplay is unique and close to fun but they decided to implement the worst item management I have ever seen. The strange heaving breasts of the female PC is just the weird icing on a stale cake. Still, if the developers learned from making this one and made a sequel with more content that looks like it was actually made for PC, I'd still check it out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023666926', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1772, 'playtime_forever': 178, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 178, 'last_played': 1510068367}
review:
I should have known better. It is mobile port so you kinda know what you might expect. 

It looked like very simple dungeon crawler that could be fun even if it was mobile game, some mobile game are great. But it is very repetitive, after one level you have  basically seen most of things  that game have to offer. 
You can buy and sell gear and craft gems that give you bonuses depends of where you put them. I don't like how crating menu and shop many is in this game, it is spinning wheel so you can easily rotate it with your thumb on phone, but this is not a phone. But most importantly what I don't like i amount of grinding you have to do to progress. There is some tactics in a game but you have to level up your character and have better gear to progress no matter how good your tactic is and you end up with grinding. Even worst part is that after a while you are bored to death, you are doing the same thing over and over again, you are just reacting to things that happening and that basically it.

Not as fun I was hoped and my hopes wasn't that high either :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198427198130', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 147, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 147, 'last_played': 1506476479}
review:
Not bad.  Fun in small doses at least.  Not enough game to play and play but it can be cool for a time.  It feels less like a dungeon adventure and more like a board game, but that's cool too.  Not a bad price for what you get.

Yes I would recommend this game.

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198297909459', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 313, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 313, 'last_played': 1500787608}
review:
trattasi di un rpg a turni, sia nello spostarsi che nei combattimenti, di stampo gotico, quindi dark e tenebroso, dotato di soundtrack dal taglio decisamente dark ambient ed in cui, dovremo principalmente affrontare dei terribili mostri affamati delle nostre carni
tutto si svolge all'interno dei dungeon che potremo vedere dall'alto, ma il tutto invece che nella piÃ¹ classica maniera, Ã¨ strutturato a caselle in cui dovremo spostarci esaminando accuratamente il terreno in cerca delle chiavi per poter procedere nel livello successivo
ma non Ã¨ detto che nella casella ci sia direttamente la chiave, la quale in realtÃ  puÃ² essere procurata solo dopo averla strappata dagli artigli di un mostro, ovviamente dopo che l'avremo ucciso
potremmo trovare dei tesori consistenti in danaro, oppure oggetti da poterci equipaggiare, o magie usa e getta, o degli oggetti che hanno un utilizzo unico nell'esplorazione del dungeon
tutto ruota intorno alla nostra insufficienza, ovvero l'incapacitÃ  di essere in grado di fronteggiare una ben cosÃ¬ terribile situazione, perchÃ© vedete, non potremo affrontare tutti i mostri che incontreremo, non ne siamo in grado e non lo saremo mai, per quanto ci possiamo ostinare a salire di livello, potenziare il nostro character negli attributi e nell'equipaggiamento, basteranno sempre pochi colpi ad i mostri per metterci KO
quindi il tutto si riduce nel trovare in fretta la chiave e nel procedere nel livello successivo prima di subire troppi danni, per fare ciÃ² avremo bisogno di astuzia e di furbizia, dovremo essere scalti ed ingegnosi, svegli ed intelligenti
nei livelli potremo trovare varie tipologie di pozioni curative del mana e dell'energia, ma fateci il callo, non sarÃ  mai abbastanza per tenerci al sicuro e riparati dalle terribili creature che infestano le caverne
tutto sommato sembrerebbe essere proprio un bel gioco, ma io dopo diverse ore di gioco ho fatto dei ben miseri progressi, ho notato solo che la difficoltÃ  Ã¨ stata mal calibrata e che avrebbe avuto bisogno di un maggior uso di beta testing, in queste condizioni sono terribilmente spiacente, non posso di certo consigliarlo

author: {'steamid': '76561197996550048', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 131, 'playtime_forever': 163, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 163, 'last_played': 1473485841}
review: incredibly boring rogue-like that relies on a tedious parrying mechanic for its combat. every encounter can be boiled down to just attacking and then blocking at the right time, with only the slightest variations on when to block between each enemy type. you can cast spells i guess, but they don't really help a whole lot and i'd always run out of mana quickly. other than that, you just uncover tiles and hope you find something good, but there honestly isn't a whole lot to find or get excited about. also, if you haven't noticed, the game's incredibly ugly. overall, there are just tons of better games similar to this you could be wasting your time on.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027267313', 'num_games_owned': 1838, 'num_reviews': 4460, 'playtime_forever': 378, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 378, 'last_played': 1505948468}
review:
Tags: Clicker - Slow
Additional Tags: Delete Local Content & Remove from Library

TLDR: Phone port of a hack and slash minesweeper style variant. Completely outcompeted by Runestone Keeper which takes the exact same concept as this game, but improves on it with more monster variety, better itemization, special abilities, resolution support and stronger audiovisuals
http://store.steampowered.com/app/339400/Runestone_Keeper/

No options menu - game area is restricted to a phone shape in the middle of your computer screen that occupies about 30 % of the screen with huge sidebars on each side. The graphics are rather basic animated 3D portraits and somewhat boring looking dirt tiles that you clear to reveal the dungeon. The gameplay with clicking on enemies to take down their health and clicking the protagonist or using spacebar to block enemy attacks, with clear visual representation of attacks to help with timing. All in all its enjoyable for what it is, but would be far more suited for its original platform and it is debatable if this is a worthwile title for a PC gaming collection

author: {'steamid': '76561198089621246', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 2773, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 399, 'last_played': 1493048678}
review: Great game, especially for the money.  Maybe not for everyone, but to me, this is an RPG solitaire, meaning I can sit down and just enjoy myself casually and relax. Other than that, plenty of content and bit more to it than you'd first think.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104101411', 'num_games_owned': 511, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 492, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 165, 'last_played': 1532219624}
review:
A great game for casuals and hardcores who just want a relaxing, dungeon crawling experience. It's one of those games that you play for an hour or two during breaks from other deep games.

Pros:
- Simple Mechanics
- Random Dungeons
- Random Spells in dungeons
- Stat System
- Rewards timing
- Familiar RPG inventory system

Depends on you:
- Some grinding

Cons:
- Repetitiveness
- Might get stale long term

author: {'steamid': '76561198126081939', 'num_games_owned': 484, 'num_reviews': 344, 'playtime_forever': 30, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1565184616}
review:
I've won this through steamgifts platform.
For me this is little gem out there. Sure the game is quite basic, and the graphic is not high as well, but this game brought me already a big chunk of fun. It reminds me quite similar title Runestone keeper, however this game emphasis on different things. It is a mix of mine sweeper with a RPG elements and arcade quick-time ones. The game has high replay ability and what I like is you can keep your character progress and gear after the death. Complexity stays, killing off everything as goes is not always best strategy, also uncovering everything, one must keep truck of creatures traits and resources available. Also there is a perception. I don't like music here very much but that is minor, and one can turn it off easily. The game could have some story, but even without it at 2 Euro tag (even much less on sales and bundles) is the game that can be easily recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027351226', 'num_games_owned': 312, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 787, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 549, 'last_played': 1587330436}
review:
I spend $30+ on a game and sometimes only play them for an hour or two. I spend .50 on this game and I'm still playing it over 6 hours later. There's a few minor things that bug me such as it taking so long to create gems and (seemingly) no way into the inventory from inside of a dungeon, but otherwise this game is on point. 

4.3 / 5

author: {'steamid': '76561198080762628', 'num_games_owned': 774, 'num_reviews': 187, 'playtime_forever': 105, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 105, 'last_played': 1484140581}
review: I was bored out of my mind while playing this, sure this would be enjoyable on your phone while waiting in public. But while playing on PC it feels like a chore, all you do is click to uncover a dungeon. That is the entire game, and while there is nothing wrong with that at least make it semi-interesting. It fails in being interesting and not at all being fun. If you're looking for a good casual Dungeon Crawler with RPG elements then I would stay away from this. This game is simply a mobile game put on Steam, and if you're OK with that and just want some mindless clicking for about 30 minutes. Then pick this up, if you look for a bit more in your games, stay away from this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015223336', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1805, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 958, 'last_played': 1620619363}

author: {'steamid': '76561197991911356', 'num_games_owned': 1278, 'num_reviews': 241, 'playtime_forever': 986, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 729, 'last_played': 1643819740}
review:
I loved Dungelot and it sequels, So I went out and bought runstone keeper knowing that it was a shameless rip off but It was a bit too grindy and felt like you needed to play level 1 1500 times to gain anything, So it sucked. Knowing that this was yet another shameless rip off I could not say no to trying this game for 50 cents. So I bought it and it definitively is a shameless rip off,

But! I was not expecting it to have alot of new things which made it very fun. It also has a gear system and lots of cool things, a blocking system which I did not really like because I did not want a dexterity based game but its not so hard.
The game also includes endless mode thankfully.

Knowing that this game is a rip off of Dungelot, I really really liked it and felt rewarded by the class unlocks although its missing some stuff from dungelot it has alot of its own unique features that make up for it and would definitively recommend it for 50 cents or even its full price of 2 dollars and because it is not grindy I enjoyed it far more than runestone keeper.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053713050', 'num_games_owned': 3050, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 90, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 90, 'last_played': 1489351052}
review:
Another Minesweeper-style dungeon exploration game, with added QTE/timing-based combat. The game itself simply doesn't seem particularly good, feeling very much as if little to no thought or effort were put into it.

Despite having a "tutorial", a five page help screen, and the ability to right click on nearly everything to see details, the game doesn't bother to ever explain basic information to the player.  The game tells you how to block, but never bothers to teach the timing of either blocking or the counter attack.  You can socket gems into equipment for bonuses, but the game never tells you this.  You just have to happen to click on a piece of equipment and then click on the non-descript empty block that appears to just be menu decoration to bring up the socketing menu.

Game mechanics just don't seem particularly well balanced.   Being able to block near perfectly is king.  You probably can't even beat the second dungeon without excellent blocking or taking advantage of the ill-explained checkpoint system.  It looks like you can min-max your stats, or easily waste your level up points if you don't know what you are doing.  Luck plays perhaps too much a part in exploration.

Not much thought or effort seems to be put into enemy design.  No enemies feel particularly special or memorable, in part due to the generically bad CG art and in part because abilities seem almost randomly assigned at times.  Multiple enemies have the ability where they get stronger every three turns.

Ultimately, the game just isn't that much fun to play. It ends up being less than the sum of its parts.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027671296', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 224, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 196, 'last_played': 1481462900}
review:
Bon petit jeu avec un gameplay archi simple (Adaptation d'un jeu smartphone?).

Ca casse pas des briques et je vais surement pas y passer des heures et des heures. Mais pour le prix (soldes d'haloween pour moi), ya de quoi s'amuser un peu.

Pour dÃ©crire un peu ce jeu, c'est un jeu de click et de timing. On explore des donjons pas forcÃ©ment de fond en comble (parce qu'il faut rester entier a la fin du niveau sous peine de recommencer celui ci) en dÃ©voilant chaque Ã©tage case par case. Niveau combat, il suffit de cliquer sur l'adversaire et de bloquer sa contre attaque au bon moment. Certains monstres ont des subtilitÃ©s que je vous laisse dÃ©couvrir ;)

Au final on se retrouve vite avec quelques heures au compteur, ce qui pour le prix est plutÃ´t pas mal.

Je reprocherais au jeu un manque de variÃ©tÃ© et de contenu (on trouve toujours les mÃªmes items au point ou chaque donjon se ressemble au point ou l'alÃ©atoire viens plus de notre capacitÃ© a avoir un bon timing ou non que du jeu en lui mÃªme.

review: It should be borning, dungeons, monstors repetitive. Plenty of potions (sometimes) plenty of gold (sometimes) and plenty of loot (most of the time.) Should be boring. But its not. I find myself drawen back again and again for just one more try at that dungeon, one more floor before I Quit. I love it. A great game for a quick gaming fix as you can leave dungeons anytime and save by exiting game afterward.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042225625', 'num_games_owned': 6556, 'num_reviews': 448, 'playtime_forever': 181, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 181, 'last_played': 1472724785}
review:
A pesky little turn-based dungeon crawler of constant clicking on things (dungeon clicker?). We open squares, collect bonuses and fight mobs. Made on Unity, no sliders to adjust sound levels, it features sloppy graphics and horribly redundant real-time mechanics of defence - you need to click quickly on self after each attack to block random percentage of the returning damage, if late you take all damage. It also has scarce one time checkpoints to aid your struggle through the long course of randomly generated rooms, but I wasn't inspired for that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034805546', 'num_games_owned': 231, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 395, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 325, 'last_played': 1568003998}
review:
This game is a great time killer. Perfect mix of strategy, skill, and RNG. You pick a class (starting as a mage) and can switch between classes as you unlock them. You enter dungeons which are grid based. You descend down them floor by floor until you reach the bottom. At the bottom there is a boss that you must defeat to complete the dungeon.

Don't worry if you keep dying, as each death lets you retry the dungeon which makes you stronger. Once you character is strong enough you should be able to complete the dungeons no problem.

The dungeon is randomly generated every time so that you aren't grinding away at the same dungeon every time and the game includes endless dungeons for replayability (great inclusion in my oppinion)

Music fits well with the games art style and gameplay. Only downside I've seen so far is some strange UI decisions and inability to use or equip items you have found on your current run. This is a great game for the price. It looks like it can be enjoyed on newer systems and older ones as well (maybe even netbooks!). Other than that I would give this game 4 out of 5 stars simply because of the fun and replayability the game has!

author: {'steamid': '76561198303733370', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 10, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10, 'last_played': 1470320390}
review:
(English)
Great "time killer" at the junction of genres roguelite and a clicker.
Dungeon jorney is a small, not demanding on the computer and quite an exciting time, representing a mix of clicker and bagel. The player assuming control of one of several typical characters (mage, knight, hunter and so on), is sent to investigate one of the dungeons in search of treasure, artifacts and bonuses. The gameplay is alternately open squares â€” sectors dungeons, each of which may be hiding the treasure, a trap or enemy. When meeting with the enemy, a lot depends on your reaction and speed with the mouse, since all battles occur in real time, and in fact are zaklikivanie enemy attacks or abilities of the hero. The enemy also attacks, and only the timely press of the block (spacebar) saves him from most of the damage. After the death of the hero loses all accumulated in the dungeon artifacts and returns to the main map, and the dungeon will be reset, which leads to the need to re-open the map floors. The same hero can be "pumped", raising its characteristics, dressing and arming, learning skills and spells and improving equipment special stones..
So the game is easy, quite fun and simple in concept a hybrid of several genres, among which are role-playing slasher, and explore the dungeons and clicker. Despite their obvious "mobile" roots of it quite well looks and plays on the computer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077155282', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 412, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 412, 'last_played': 1467354780}
review:
For the price this is fantastic!  Simple to play, medium depth of complexity so it's easy to understand and good strategy with checkpoints in dungeons every 5 levels.

For the price this is great and a hidden gem!

author: {'steamid': '76561198170652846', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 825, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 825, 'last_played': 1467123728}
review:
I don't know if this was originally a mobile game, but it looks like it.
It's simple but fun, and that's what games should be.
You click to explore cells like minesweeper, but instead of mines you find monsters or items.
Plus it's a roguelike.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005149103', 'num_games_owned': 858, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 171, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 171, 'last_played': 1467021904}

author: {'steamid': '76561198126351014', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 30, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1467377125}
review:
Not too bad of a game, granted I feel like I am playing a smartphone port to pc.. Combat is simple enough and the gameplay reminds me of minesweeper. Feels like it could be a great time waster, or at least something to play casually.. Like most games I play, this review and game are not for everyone. The animation and graphics are nice, with the option to turn off the 3d characters. The sound quality is great. 

Easy enough to handle, casually play, explore the minsweeper-esque dungeon.. Basic rpg type leveling and limited skills.

Not for everyone but at sale price you only lose pocket change if you don't like it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975295227', 'num_games_owned': 1880, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 1900, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 358, 'last_played': 1680203876}
review: I'll leave the details to the pros.  What I'll say about this game is it's an exceptionally fun casual RPG.  It's a perfect game for after a long day. Not to intense but won't put you to sleep either. I love this game and can't recommend it more!

author: {'steamid': '76561198298458651', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 760, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 621, 'last_played': 1467021280}
review: this is a very fun game and cheap. i seem to pay 5x as much for games i never play, and this gem is worth it for sure. only dislikes are the merchant item prchase. this game gets you used to clicking clicking and clacking, and when you save up to buy item, you sometimes go too fast and click and accidentally buy crap you then have to sell back for 10%. or at least my dumass did.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988663774', 'num_games_owned': 3547, 'num_reviews': 351, 'playtime_forever': 541, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 541, 'last_played': 1466569274}
review:
Meh... not much to say about this. It's a fairly simple RPG in which you uncover tiles which have loot, potions, spells, monsters, or nothing behind them. Loot you pick up, potions you pick up if you need them or at the end of the stage, spells you cast if you need to (so, basically never in my experience), and monsters you have to fight.

The combat system is based on timing, insofar as you have to press the spacebar when the enemy swings at you in order to reduce damage, and then click on the enemy immediately after to do a critical hit for massive damage. By the middle of the game I had nearly 100% damage reduction on a successful block, and at the end of the game I had a full 100%, so "block correctly and then attack again right away for massive damage" was the entirety of the strategy in the game, with me almost never using spells found on the ground and rarely using my character skills - only against the few types of enemies where I wasn't very good at timing their attacks. If you're better than me at it, even that wouldn't be necessary.

It still wasn't all that easy, because failing to block an attack could easily cost half of my life instantly, and the checkpoint system made the final dungeon occasionally frustrating, in that there's a checkpoint every five levels... but if you die and respawn at the checkpoint, you need to reach the next checkpoint before dying or be sent back to the start of the dungeon. This isn't so bad until you consider that each dungeon is five floors longer than the last, culminating in a 50-floor dungeon.

Furthermore, the mechanics for your stats are... weird. You first find dropped items that barely do much, and gems you can socket in your items that give small bonuses that are still the equivalent of the entire item's bonuses due to how little the items do. Then you unlock the merchant, who sells items... except they still don't do much, and its catalog expanding throughout the game basically means you'll never be able to afford them. And then you unlock the mystic and the ability to fuse gems, and suddenly your items still don't do much, but have gems in them that give gigantic stat bonuses, bigger than both the base items and your levelups. And then, near the end of the game, you unlock the blacksmith and the ability to upgrade items, and suddenly your items also give huge bonuses... two maps or so before the end of the game.

Anyway, ultimately... well, it's a $2 game. It not having much depth - not even an ending or anything once I beat the final boss - is to be expected to some degree, but I also felt it didn't have much of a point, either, and it was more tedious than fun. It's definitely not going to show up on any "worst game of 2016"-style lists, but I don't think it's worth your time to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985497697', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 249, 'last_played': 1473552899}
review:
This is an excellent game combining smartphone-sized roguelike dungeons with a battle system not unlike how trading card games work. It's very easy to get into to the gameplay, yet does it demand a combination of risk management, strategic thinking and quicktime reaction to actually survive whatever the game throws at you. Don't be fooled by the gameplay trailer - the game flow is solely based on the pace of your actions and you should think twice or even thrice about what to do next. Additionally, it's worth to note that game generates a distinct audiovisual atmosphere of it's own and you feel immediately entangled by the very gods of random number generation.

Bought it for 0,59â‚¬ but the full price of 1,99â‚¬ is absolutely worth it. If you like well crafted roguelikish games with their own flair, this is perfect for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036494887', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 196, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 194, 'last_played': 1478147378}
review:
really fun, and really cheap.
I dont understand the negative reviews. the top voted one just says he doesn't like dieing and having to start the level again, IÂ´ll quote:
 ''There's nothing worse than saving your spot on level 40 in a dungeon; dying at level 45; respawning at level 41; dying, again before the next save spot; and, finally, respawning at level 1 as the save spots are only good for one death. Talk about a waste of time. ''

Have you ever heard of rogue like? and that's not even the case. seeing as you keep all your progress and there are checkpoints every 5 dungeon levels, so what if the checkpoints only work once? youÂ´ll be stronger anyway.

enough about answering the haters, let me talk about the game:
-itÂ´s like a grid board game where you reveal squares in a dungeon until you find the key to go to the next floor, each square you reveal can be a monster, gold, item or a spell(each char has their own spells and abilities, but there are also random spells you can find and use once).
-there are 2 classes initially and you can unlock other 3
-there is an inventory and every equipment has a socket where you can insert gems to make it stronger.
-you get xp and you keep your progress
-fights are not only mindless clicking, it involves skill, because when you hit a monster it will hit you back and you have to block ate the right time and counter-atack
-the dev answered all my questions right away

in short, itÂ´s an amazing game and itÂ´s worth way more than they are asking for it

author: {'steamid': '76561198005989512', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 514, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 514, 'last_played': 1465677446}
review:
Despite the cheap price, it's not worth more than a couple hours of your time...even if you get it free.  It was fun the first couple of hours until I realized that >80% of the game is repetitive and boring.  There are five different classes you can play, but I couldn't bring myself to finish one class, let alone five.

There's nothing worse than saving your spot on level 40 in a dungeon; dying at level 45; respawning at level 41; dying, again before the next save spot; and, finally, respawning at level 1 as the save spots are only good for one death.  Talk about a waste of time.  If there were at least a story, I would have tried a couple more times.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013217828', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 448, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 447, 'last_played': 1479218787}
review:
Dungeon Journey is very clearly a ported smartphone game. That said, it does work as a PC gameâ€”if your screen is very small, or you're willing to do some registry fiddling to change the resolution of the game window. (For information on how to do this, look [url=http://steamcommunity.com/app/485490/discussions/0/350532795325928509/]here[/url].)

The game itself is a simple, casual roguelike. It's enjoyable and engaging enough to be worthwhile, although hardly unique or very memorable. Strategy-wise, there is some (if not very much) depth here, and although the practical use of some elements (such as Perception) don't become apparent until you've sunk quite a few points into them, most of the gameplay is fairly intuitive and presents itself well.

There is a hitch, however. The entire point of a casual game is to be noncommittal and not require total focus, but one of the core elements of Dungeon Journey (the shield block) is reaction-based, and thus repeatedly forces the player to concentrate entirely on playing rather than treating the game as the casual distraction it is clearly intended to be. This is unlikely to be an issue for everyone, but it can get highly frustrating for some of us.

The audio side is passable. The UI and game sounds are pretty professional. The music does sometimes get rather annoying (mostly, I think, because it's badly compressed) but then it's a casual game. For my part, I simply turned all sound off once I realised that none of it gives any gameplay advantage.

Dungeon Journey is not a bad little game, and for the low price, it is easy to forgive the lack of polish (poor English, incomplete tutorial, subpar graphics, and so on.) If you're looking for a hardcore, involving and comprehensively strategic roguelike, look elsewhereâ€”but if like me you're simply looking for something to mess around with when your concentration isn't strictly needed elsewhere, then Dungeon Journey might well be the ticket.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997753397', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 724, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 407, 'last_played': 1593548349}
review: Well, for $1.19 you really can't go wrong with this game, a very entertaining casual rougelike dungeon game, the sort that keeps you playing to uncover just one more square and before you know it you have sunk several hours into it. there is also quite a bit of Strategy that becomes apparent once you get some lvls in perception and you are able to plan ahead to plot your course through the unexplored squares. Frankly its a lot better than some of the casual games that I have paid up to $15 for! a worthy effort indeed for just over a dollar!

author: {'steamid': '76561197995436761', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 178, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 60, 'last_played': 1660421555}
review:
It looks like I'm the first to review this little gem in English. Dungeon Journey is a cousin of Rune Stone Keeper and Dungelot and that's a very goodthing. Unlike the previous games however some reflexes are required. When a monster attacks you need to hit the space bar at the right time to minimize damage.

The game clearly looks like it is made for phones. I don't mind what the platform is as long as the game play is fun. The graphics are quite nice and the game has a fun sense of humor. There are two endless dungeon areas that will be unlocked on your journey. You are faced with some interesting choices as you delve deeper. Not sure what that spell does? Right click it and you get the skinny on it. Your character levels up but remember that this is a roguelike so don't get too attached.

It's no epic journey like Legend of Grimrock or the classic Dungeon Keeper. Rather, it's a fun game to fire up when you just want some simple fun.
